tit.e: Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu)
Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu)
Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu)

sen.j: 神武東征（じんむとうせい）は、天皇家の初代カムヤマトイワレビコ（神武天皇）が日向を発ち、大和を征服して橿原宮で即位するまでの日本神話の説話である。
sen.e: Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) is a tale in Japanese myth of the expedition of Kamuyamatoiwarebiko (Emperor Jinmu) who was the first generation of the Imperial family, from his departure from Hyuga, conquest of Yamato and coronation at Kashiwara no Miya (palace at Kashihara).

Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) is a tale in Japanese myth of the expedition of the first Kamuyamatoiwarebiko (Emperor Jinmu) of the Imperial family who departed from Hyuga, conquered Yamato and succeeded to Kashiwara no Miya (palace at Kashihara).
sen.cmt: expedition以降の分を修正しました。
sen.e: Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) is a tale in Japanese myth of the expedition of the first Kamuyamatoiwarebiko (Emperor Jinmu) of the Imperial family who departed from Hyuga, conquered Yamato and succeeded to Kashiwara no Miya (palace at Kashihara).

sen.j: この神話の解釈としては、全くの創作であるという説と、九州にあった勢力が大和に移ってきてヤマト王権を築いたという史実を神話化して伝えたものであるという説がある。
sen.e: Some understand that this is completely fictitious, while others believe that this myth is based on the historical fact that a power in Kyushu moved to Yamato to build the Yamato Dynasty.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Some understand that this is completely fictitious, while others believe that this myth is based on the historical fact that a power in Kyushu moved to Yamato to build the Yamato Dynasty.
Some understand that this is completely fictitious, while others believe that this myth is based on the historical fact that a power in Kyushu moved to Yamato to build the Yamato Dynasty.

sen.j: 信用すべき同時代の文字資料が現れない限り、神武東征を学問的に立証するのは困難であろう。
sen.e: It seems difficult to prove Jimmu tosei academically unless trustworthy written documents of the time are found.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It seems difficult to prove Jimmu tosei academically unless trustworthy written documents of the time are found.
It seems difficult to prove Jimmu tosei academically unless trustworthy written documents of the time are found.

sen.j: 九州にいた天皇が大和を制圧するという点で、後の神功皇后・応神天皇母子との類似性が指摘される事がある。
sen.e: A similarity to Empress Jingu and her son Emperor Ojin is pointed out because in both stories an emperor in Kyushu conquered Yamato.
A similarity to the later Empress Jingu and her son Emperor Ojin is pointed out because in both stories an emperor in Kyushu conquered Yamato.
A similarity to the later Empress Jingu and her son Emperor Ojin is pointed out because in both stories an emperor in Kyushu conquered Yamato.

sen.j: また神話学者の三品彰英により、高句麗の建国神話との類似が指摘されている。
sen.e: A mythologist Shoei MISHINA also pointed out the similarity to the myth of national foundation of Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea).
A mythologist Shoei MISHINA also pointed out the similarity to the myth of national foundation of Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea).
A mythologist Shoei MISHINA also pointed out the similarity to the myth of national foundation of Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea).

sen.j: あらすじ
sen.e: Story outline
Story line
Story line

sen.j: 古事記
sen.e: Kojiki
Kojiki
Kojiki

sen.j: 『古事記』では、神倭伊波礼毘古命（カムヤマトイワレビコ）は、兄のイツセ（イツセ）とともに、日向の高千穂でどこへ行けばもっと良く葦原中国を治められるだろうかと相談し、東へ行くことにした。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Kamuyamatoiwarebiko conferred with his elder brother Itsuse where they should move to rule Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of Reed Plains) better and decided to head for east.

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Kamuyamatoiwarebiko conferred with his elder brother Itsuse where they should move to rule Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of Reed Plains) better and decided to head for east.

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Kamuyamatoiwarebiko conferred with his elder brother Itsuse where they should move to rule Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of Reed Plains) better and decided to head for east.

sen.j: 舟軍を率いて日向を出発して筑紫へ向かい、豊国の宇沙（現 宇佐市）に着くと、宇沙都比古（ウサツヒコ）・宇沙都比売（ウサツヒメ）の二人が仮宮を作って食事を差し上げた。
sen.e: Leading the army on ship, he left Hyuga and headed for Tsukushi; when they arrived at Usa (present-day Usa City) in Toyo Province, Usatsuhiko and Usatsuhime built a temporary palace and served meals.
Leading the army on ship, he left Hyuga for Tsukushi and when they arrived at Usa (present-day Usa City) in Toyo Province, Usatsuhiko and Usatsuhime built a temporary palace and served meals.
sen.cmt: he left Hyuga and headed for Tsukushi; when の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: Leading the army on ship, he left Hyuga for Tsukushi and when they arrived at Usa (present-day Usa City) in Toyo Province, Usatsuhiko and Usatsuhime built a temporary palace and served meals.

sen.j: そこから移動して、岡田宮で1年過ごした。
sen.e: They moved to Okadagu where they spent a year.
They moved to Okadagu where they spent a year.
They moved to Okadagu where they spent a year.

sen.j: さらに進んで安芸国の多祁理宮（たけりのみや）で7年、吉備国の高島宮で8年過ごした。
sen.e: Then they moved forward to Takeri no miya in Aki Province where they spent seven years and at Takashima no miya in Kibi Province for eight years.
Then they moved forward to Takeri no miya in Aki Province where they spent seven years and at Takashima no miya in Kibi Province eight years.
Then they moved forward to Takeri no miya in Aki Province where they spent seven years and at Takashima no miya in Kibi Province eight years.

sen.j: 浪速国の白肩津（現 東大阪市附近。当時はこの辺りまで入江があった）に停泊すると、長髄彦が軍勢を起こして待ち構えていた。
sen.e: When the army anchored at Shirakata no tsu (Bay of Shirakata) in Naniwa Province (near present-day Higashi Osaka City; there was a bay at that time), Nagasunehiko had raised the army and been preparing for the landing of Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.

When the army anchored at Shirakata no tsu (Bay of Shirakata) in Naniwa Province (near present-day Higashi Osaka City. There was a bay at that time), Nagasunehiko had been waiting for the landing of Kamuyamatoiwarebiko with his army.
sen.cmt: 後半部分を少し修正しました。
sen.e: When the army anchored at Shirakata no tsu (Bay of Shirakata) in Naniwa Province (near present-day Higashi Osaka City. There was a bay at that time), Nagasunehiko had been waiting for the landing of Kamuyamatoiwarebiko with his army.

sen.j: ナガスネヒコと戦っている時に、イツセはナガスネヒコが放った矢に当たってしまった。
sen.e: In the battle with Nagasunehiko, Itsuse was shot by Nagatsunehiko's arrow.
In the battle with Nagasunehiko, Itsuse was shot by Nagatsunehiko's arrow.
In the battle with Nagasunehiko, Itsuse was shot by Nagatsunehiko's arrow.

sen.j: イツセは、「我々は日の神の御子だから、日に向かって（東を向いて）戦うのは良くない。
sen.e: Itsuse said, "We are the sons of Hi no kami (the Sun Goddess i.e. Amaterasu Omikami), so we shouldn't fight facing the sun (the East).
Itsuse said, "We are the sons of Hi no kami (the Sun Goddess i.e. Amaterasu Omikami), so we shouldn't fight facing the sun (the East).
Itsuse said, "We are the sons of Hi no kami (the Sun Goddess i.e. Amaterasu Omikami), so we shouldn't fight facing the sun (the East).

sen.j: 廻り込んで日を背にして（西を向いて）戦おう」と言った。
sen.e: We should move to fight with the Sun on our back (facing the West)."
We should move to fight with the Sun on our back (facing the West)."
We should move to fight with the Sun on our back (facing the West)."

sen.j: それで南の方へ回り込んだが、イツセは紀伊国の男之水門に着いた所で亡くなってしまった。
sen.e: So they moved toward the South, but Itsuse died when they arrived at Onominato in Kii Province.
So they moved toward the South, but Itsuse died when they arrived at Onominato in Kii Province.
So they moved toward the South, but Itsuse died when they arrived at Onominato in Kii Province.

sen.j: カムヤマトイワレビコが熊野まで来た時、大熊が現われてすぐに消えた。
sen.e: When Kamuyamatoiwarebiko arrived at Kumano, a huge bear appeared and immediately disappeared.
When Kamuyamatoiwarebiko arrived at Kumano, a huge bear appeared and immediately disappeared.
When Kamuyamatoiwarebiko arrived at Kumano, a huge bear appeared and immediately disappeared.

sen.j: するとカムヤマトイワレビコを始め兵士たちは皆気を失って倒れてしまった。
sen.e: After the bear vanished, Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and his army fainted.
Then, Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and his army fainted.
sen.cmt: 文の最初の部分を省きました。
sen.e: Then, Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and his army fainted.

sen.j: この時、熊野の高倉下（タカクラジ）が、一振りの太刀を持ってやって来ると、カムヤマトイワレビコはすぐに目が覚めた。
sen.e: Then, Takakuraji from Kumano came to them with a sword and Kamuyamatoiwarebiko woke up immediately.
Then, Takakuraji from Kumano came to them with a sword and Kamuyamatoiwarebiko woke up immediately.
Then, Takakuraji from Kumano came to them with a sword and Kamuyamatoiwarebiko woke up immediately.

sen.j: カムヤマトイワレビコがその太刀を受け取ると、熊野の荒ぶる神は自然に切り倒されてしまい、倒れていた兵士も気絶から覚めた。
sen.e: When Kamuyamatoiwarebiko received the sword, a rough deity in Kumano was cut down naturally and all the fainted army were awaken.
When Kamuyamatoiwarebiko received the sword, a rough deity in Kumano was cut down naturally and all the fainted army awoke.
When Kamuyamatoiwarebiko received the sword, a rough deity in Kumano was cut down naturally and all the fainted army awoke.

sen.j: カムヤマトイワレビコはタカクラジに太刀を手に入れた経緯を尋ねた。
sen.e: Kamuyamatoiwarebiko asked Takakuraji how he received the sword.
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko asked Takakuraji how he received the sword.
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko asked Takakuraji how he received the sword.

sen.j: タカクラジによれば、タカクラジの夢の中にアマテラスとタカミムスビが現れた。
sen.e: Takakuraji said that Amaterasu and Takamimusubi appeared in his dream.
Takakuraji said that Amaterasu and Takamimusubi appeared in his dream.
Takakuraji said that Amaterasu and Takamimusubi appeared in his dream.

sen.j: 二神はタケミカヅチを呼んで、「葦原中国はひどく騒然としており、私の御子たちは悩んでいる。お前は葦原中国を平定させたのだから、再び天降りなさい」と命じた。
sen.e: Two deities called Takemikazuchi and said, "Ashihara Nakatsukuni is in an uproar, and our children are in trouble; you are the one who pacified Ashihara no Nakatsukuni, so you should descend to there again."

Two deities called Takemikazuchi and said, "Ashihara Nakatsukuni is in an uproar, and our children are in trouble. You are the one who pacified Ashihara no Nakatsukuni, so you should fall from the heaven again."
sen.cmt: ; you→. Youに、descend to there→fall from the heavenに修正しました。
sen.e: Two deities called Takemikazuchi and said, "Ashihara Nakatsukuni is in an uproar, and our children are in trouble. You are the one who pacified Ashihara no Nakatsukuni, so you should fall from the heaven again."

sen.j: が、タケミカヅチは「平定の時に使った太刀があるので、その刀を降ろしましょう」と答えた。
sen.e: Takemikazuchi answered, "Instead, I will provide the sword that I used in pacification."
Takemikazuchi answered, "Instead, I will provide the sword that I used in pacification."
Takemikazuchi answered, "Instead, I will provide the sword that I used in pacification."

sen.j: そしてタカクラジに、「倉の屋根に穴を空けてそこから太刀を落とし入れるから、天津神の御子の元に持って行きなさい」と言った。
sen.e: Then he said to Takakuraji, "I will make a hole on the roof of the warehouse and throw in the sword, so you should bring it to the child of Amatsukami (god of heaven)."
Then he said to Takakuraji, "I will make a hole on the roof of the warehouse and throw in the sword, so you should bring it to the child of Amatsukami (god of heaven)."
Then he said to Takakuraji, "I will make a hole on the roof of the warehouse and throw in the sword, so you should bring it to the child of Amatsukami (god of heaven)."

sen.j: 目が覚めて自分の倉を見ると本当に太刀があったので、こうして持って来たという。
sen.e: When he woke up and looked into his warehouse, the sword was there as described, so he brought it to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.
When he woke up and looked into his warehouse, the sword was there as described, so he brought it to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.
When he woke up and looked into his warehouse, the sword was there as described, so he brought it to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.

sen.j: その太刀はミカフツ神、またはフツノミタマと言い、現在は石上神宮に鎮座している。
sen.e: The sword is called Mikafutsu no kami or Futsu no mitama, and it is now enshrined at Isonokami-jingu Shrine.
The sword is called Mikafutsu no kami or Futsu no mitama, and it is now enshrined at Isonokami-jingu Shrine.
The sword is called Mikafutsu no kami or Futsu no mitama, and it is now enshrined at Isonokami-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: また、高木神の命令で八咫烏が遣わされ、その案内で熊野から大和の宇陀に至った。
sen.e: By the order of Takagi no kami, yatagarasu (Japanese mythological big crow) was sent as a guide to follow from Kumano to Uda in Yamato Province.
By the order of Takagi no kami, yatagarasu (Japanese mythological big crow) was sent as a guide to lead from Kumano to Uda in Yamato Province.
By the order of Takagi no kami, yatagarasu (Japanese mythological big crow) was sent as a guide to lead from Kumano to Uda in Yamato Province.

sen.j: 宇陀には兄宇迦斯（エウカシ）・弟宇迦斯（オトウカシ）の兄弟がいた。
sen.e: In Uda, they met brothers Eukashi and Otoukashi.
In Uda, they met brothers Eukashi and Otoukashi.
In Uda, they met brothers Eukashi and Otoukashi.

sen.j: まず八咫烏を遣わして、カムヤマトイワレビコに仕えるかどうか尋ねさせたが、兄のエウカシは鳴鏑を射て追い返してしまった。
sen.e: Kamuyamatoiwarebiko sent the yatakarasu first to ask the brothers whether they would serve him or not, but Eukashi shot a whistling arrowhead to chase the bird away.
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko sent the yatakarasu first to ask the brothers whether they would serve him or not, but the older brother Eukashi shot a whistling arrowhead to chase the bird away.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「兄の」を補足しました。
sen.e: Kamuyamatoiwarebiko sent the yatakarasu first to ask the brothers whether they would serve him or not, but the older brother Eukashi shot a whistling arrowhead to chase the bird away.

sen.j: エウカシは軍勢を集めて迎え撃とうとしたが、軍勢を集めることができなかった。
sen.e: Eukashi tried to gather the army to fight against Kamuyamatoiwarebiko but failed.
Eukashi tried to gather the army to fight against Kamuyamatoiwarebiko but failed.
Eukashi tried to gather the army to fight against Kamuyamatoiwarebiko but failed.

sen.j: そこで、カムヤマトイワレビコに仕えると偽って、御殿を作ってその中に、入ると天井が落ちてくる罠を仕掛けた。
sen.e: So he pretended to serve Kamuyamatoiwarebiko by building a palace with a trap that the ceiling would fall once a person entered.
So he pretended to serve Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and built a palace with a trap that the ceiling would fall once a person entered.
So he pretended to serve Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and built a palace with a trap that the ceiling would fall once a person entered.

sen.j: 弟のオトウカシはカムヤマトイワレビコにこのことを報告した。
sen.e: Otoukashi the younger reported this trick to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.
The younger brother Otoukashi reported this trick to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.
sen.cmt: 「弟の」の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: The younger brother Otoukashi reported this trick to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.

sen.j: そこでカムヤマトイワレビコは、大伴連らの祖の道臣命（ミチノオミ）と久米直らの祖の大久米命（オオクメ）をエウカシの元に遣わた。
sen.e: So Kamuyamatoiwarebiko sent Michinoomi no mikoto, the ancestor of Otomo Muraji, and Okume no mikoto, the ancestor of Kume no Atai, to Eukashi.
So Kamuyamatoiwarebiko sent Michinoomi no mikoto, the ancestor of Otomo Muraji, and Okume no mikoto, the ancestor of Kume no Atai, to Eukashi.
So Kamuyamatoiwarebiko sent Michinoomi no mikoto, the ancestor of Otomo Muraji, and Okume no mikoto, the ancestor of Kume no Atai, to Eukashi.

sen.j: 二神は矢をつがえて「仕えるというなら、その仕えるための御殿にまずお前が入って仕える様子を見せろ」とエウカシに迫った。
sen.e: Preparing arrows on their bows, two deities urged Eukashi, "If you honestly serve Kamuyamatoiwarebiko, enter the palace to prove your loyalty."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Preparing arrows on their bows, two deities urged Eukashi, "If you honestly serve Kamuyamatoiwarebiko, enter the palace to prove your loyalty."
Preparing arrows on their bows, two deities urged Eukashi, "If you honestly serve Kamuyamatoiwarebiko, enter the palace to prove your loyalty."

sen.j: エウカシは自分が仕掛けた罠にかかって死んでしまった。
sen.e: Eukashi was caught in the self-set trap and died.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Eukashi was caught in the self-set trap and died.
Eukashi was caught in the self-set trap and died.

sen.j: 忍坂の地まで来たとき、土雲の八十建（数多くの勇者）が待ち構えていた。
sen.e: When the army reached Oshisaka, Yasotakeru (numerous fighters) of Tsuchigumo were waiting for them.
When the army reached Oshisaka, Yasotakeru (numerous fighters) of Tsuchigumo were waiting for them.
When the army reached Oshisaka, Yasotakeru (numerous fighters) of Tsuchigumo were waiting for them.

sen.j: そこでカムヤマトイワレビコは八十建に御馳走を与え、八十建に対して80人の調理人をつけ、調理人に刀をしのばせた。
sen.e: Kamuyamatoiwarebiko gave them a feast and made them accompanied by 80 cooks who secretly had swords.
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko gave them a feast and made them accompanied by 80 cooks who secretly had swords.
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko gave them a feast and made them accompanied by 80 cooks who secretly had swords.

sen.j: そして合図とともに一斉に打ち殺した。
sen.e: On a sign, they killed Yasotakeru all together.
On a sign, they killed Yasotakeru all together.
On a sign, they killed Yasotakeru all together.

sen.j: その後、登美毘古（ナガスネヒコ）と戦い、兄師木（エシキ）・弟師木（オトシキ）と戦った。
sen.e: After that, the army fought against Tomibiko (another name of Nagasunehiko) and brothers Eshiki and Otoshiki.
After that, the army fought against Tomibiko (another name of Nagasunehiko) and brothers Eshiki and Otoshiki.
After that, the army fought against Tomibiko (another name of Nagasunehiko) and brothers Eshiki and Otoshiki.

sen.j: そこに邇芸速日命（ニギハヤヒ）が参上し、天津神の御子としての印の品物を差し上げて仕えた。
sen.e: Then Nigihayahi no mikoto appeared, submitted Kamuyamatoiwarebiko a symbol item as the child of Amatsu kami, and served him.
Then Nigihayahi no mikoto appeared, submitted Kamuyamatoiwarebiko a symbol item as the child of Amatsu kami, and served him.
Then Nigihayahi no mikoto appeared, submitted Kamuyamatoiwarebiko a symbol item as the child of Amatsu kami, and served him.

sen.j: このようにして荒ぶる神たちを服従させ、畝火の白檮原宮（畝傍山の東南の橿原の宮）で即位した。
sen.e: Kamuyamatoiwarebiko made rough deities to be obedient to him before ascending the throne at the palace of Kashiwara at Wnebi (the Kashihara Imperial Palace in the southeast of Mount Unebi).
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko made rough deities obey him and succeeded to the throne at the palace of Kashiwara at Unebi (the Kashihara Imperial Palace in the southeast of Mount Unebi).
sen.cmt: to be obedient→obey、 before ascending→and succeeded、 Wnebi→Unebi
sen.e: Kamuyamatoiwarebiko made rough deities obey him and succeeded to the throne at the palace of Kashiwara at Unebi (the Kashihara Imperial Palace in the southeast of Mount Unebi).

sen.j: その後、大物主の子である比売多多良伊須気余理比売（ヒメタタライスケヨリヒメ）を皇后とし、日子八井命（ヒコヤイ）、神八井耳命（カムヤイミミ）、神沼河耳命（カムヌナカワミミ、後の綏靖天皇）の三柱の子を生んだ。
sen.e: After coronation, he married Himetataraisukeyorihime, a daughter of Omono Nushi, and had three children (mihashira): Hikoyai no mikoto, Kamuyaimimi no mikoto, and Kamununakawamimi no mikoto (later Emperor Suizei).

After coronation, he married Himetataraisukeyorihime, a daughter of Omono Nushi, and had three children (mihashira): Hikoyai no mikoto, Kamuyaimimi no mikoto, and Kamununakawamimi no mikoto (later Emperor Suizei).

After coronation, he married Himetataraisukeyorihime, a daughter of Omono Nushi, and had three children (mihashira): Hikoyai no mikoto, Kamuyaimimi no mikoto, and Kamununakawamimi no mikoto (later Emperor Suizei).

sen.j: 日本書紀
sen.e: Nihonshoki
Nihonshoki
Nihonshoki

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では神日本磐余彦（カムヤマトイワレビコ）は45歳（数え）の時、天祖ニニギが天降ってから179万2470余年になるが、遠くの地では争い事が多く、塩土老翁（シオツツノオジ）によれば東に美しい国があるそうだから、そこへ行って都を作ろうと思うと言って、東征に出た。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Kanyamato Iwarehiko (Kamuyamatoiwarebiko) was 45 (age by the traditional Japanese system), or some 1,792,470 years after Amatsuoya Ninigi descended to the earth, when he worried that there were numerous disputes in the far land and heard from Shiotsuchinooji about a beautiful province in the east, so he set out for the eastern expedition to build the capital.

According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), when Kanyamato Iwarehiko (Kamuyamatoiwarebiko) was 45 (age by the traditional Japanese system), or some 1,792,470 years after Amatsuoya Ninigi descended to the earth, he said that there were numerous disputes in the far land and heard from Shiotsuchinooji about a beautiful province in the east, so he set out for the eastern expedition to build the capital.

According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), when Kanyamato Iwarehiko (Kamuyamatoiwarebiko) was 45 (age by the traditional Japanese system), or some 1,792,470 years after Amatsuoya Ninigi descended to the earth, he said that there were numerous disputes in the far land and heard from Shiotsuchinooji about a beautiful province in the east, so he set out for the eastern expedition to build the capital.

sen.j: ナガスネヒコとの戦いでは、戦いの最中、金色の鵄（とび）が飛んできてカムヤマトイワレビコの弓の先にとまった。
sen.e: In the battle against Nagasunehiko, a golden kite (a bird of prey) flied over to the tip of Kamuyamatoiwarebiko's arrow.
In the battle against Nagasunehiko, a golden kite (a bird of prey) flied over to the tip of Kamuyamatoiwarebiko's arrow.
In the battle against Nagasunehiko, a golden kite (a bird of prey) flied over to the tip of Kamuyamatoiwarebiko's arrow.

sen.j: 金鵄は光り輝き、ナガスネヒコの軍は眩惑されて戦うことができなくなった。
sen.e: The glittering golden kite mesmerized Nagasunehiko's army who couldn't fight any more.
The glittering golden kite mesmerized Nagasunehiko's army, who couldn't fight any more.
sen.cmt: コンマを補足しました。
sen.e: The glittering golden kite mesmerized Nagasunehiko's army, who couldn't fight any more.

sen.j: ナガスネヒコはカムヤマトイワレビコの元に使いを送り、自らが祀る櫛玉饒速日命（クシタマニギハヤヒ）は昔天磐船に乗って天降ったのであり、天津神が二人もいるのはおかしいから、あなたは偽物だろう、と言った。
sen.e: Nagasunehiko sent a messenger to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko to tell him that Nagasunehiko worshiped Kushitama Nigihayahi no Mikoto who descended from the heaven on Amenoiwafune Ship, and there should not be two gods of heaven, thus Kamuyamatoiwarebiko should be a fake.

Nagasunehiko sent a messenger to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko to tell him that Nagasunehiko worshiped Kushitama Nigihayahi no Mikoto who fell from the heaven on Amenoiwafune Ship, and there should not be two Amatsu kami, thus Kamuyamatoiwarebiko should be a fake.
sen.cmt: descend→fell、gods of heaven→次の文の中でAmatsu kamiとあるので修正しました。
sen.e: Nagasunehiko sent a messenger to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko to tell him that Nagasunehiko worshiped Kushitama Nigihayahi no Mikoto who fell from the heaven on Amenoiwafune Ship, and there should not be two Amatsu kami, thus Kamuyamatoiwarebiko should be a fake.

sen.j: カムヤマトイワレビコとナガスネヒコは共に天津神の御子の印を見せ合い、どちらも本物であることがわかった。
sen.e: Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and Nagasunehiko showed each other their symbol as a child of Amatsu kami, so both of them were proved to be genuine.
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and Nagasunehiko showed each other their symbols as a child of Amatsu kami, so both of them were proved to be genuine.
Kamuyamatoiwarebiko and Nagasunehiko showed each other their symbols as a child of Amatsu kami, so both of them were proved to be genuine.

sen.j: しかし、ナガスネヒコはそれでも戦いを止めようとしなかったので、ニギハヤヒはナガスネヒコを殺してカムヤマトイワレビコに帰順した。
sen.e: Nagasunehiko still refused to stop fighting, so Nigihayahi killed Nagasunehiko and submitted to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.
Nagasunehiko still refused to stop fighting, so Nigihayahi killed Nagasunehiko and submitted to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.
Nagasunehiko still refused to stop fighting, so Nigihayahi killed Nagasunehiko and submitted to Kamuyamatoiwarebiko.

sen.j: 解説
sen.e: Explanation
Explanation
Explanation

sen.j: あくまで神話の内容ではあるが、本来の伝承として神武東征の出発地について主に二つの説がある。
sen.e: There are two main theories on the place of departure of Jinmu tosei as the tradition, although these relate to the descriptions of the myth.
There are two main theories on the place of departure of Jinmu tosei as the original tradition, although these relate to the descriptions of the myth.
There are two main theories on the place of departure of Jinmu tosei as the original tradition, although these relate to the descriptions of the myth.

sen.j: 南九州説
sen.e: South Kyushu theory
Southern Kyushu theory
Southern Kyushu theory

sen.j: 日向の高千穂を文字通り日向の国（宮崎県）の高千穂とするもの。
sen.e: This theory argues that Takachiho in Hyuga literally refers to Takachiho in Hyuga Province (Miyazaki Prefecture).
This theory argues that Takachiho in Hyuga literally refers to Takachiho in Hyuga Province (Miyazaki Prefecture).
This theory argues that Takachiho in Hyuga literally refers to Takachiho in Hyuga Province (Miyazaki Prefecture).

sen.j: 根拠は以下の通り。

sen.j: 日向は日向の国である。
sen.e: Hyuga refers to Hyuga Province.
Hyuga refers to Hyuga Province.
Hyuga refers to Hyuga Province.

sen.j: ただし、高千穂を高千穂峰とする説、高千穂峡とする説等に分かれる。
sen.e: This theory is divided, however, into groups depending on what Takachiho refers to, i.e. Takachiho-no-mine Mountain, Takachiho Gorge, and so on.
This theory is divided, however, into groups depending on what Takachiho refers to, i.e. Takachiho-no-mine Mountain, Takachiho Gorge, and so on.
This theory is divided, however, into groups depending on what Takachiho refers to, i.e. Takachiho-no-mine Mountain, Takachiho Gorge, and so on.

sen.j: 扶桑社の歴史教科書では旧国定教科書と同様の説を採っているが、掲載された地図では、高千穂峰を宮崎市近くの海岸に設定し、神武一行は関門海峡手前で引き返し東に向かった形になっている。
sen.e: Fusosha's history textbook takes the same theory as the former government-designated textbook, but the map in Fusosha edition specifies Takachiho-no-mine Mountain on the coast near Miyazaki City, and the Kanmu troop tuned back near Kanmon-kaikyo Strait and headed east.

Fusosha's history textbook takes the same theory as the former government-designated textbook, but the map in Fusosha edition specifies Takachiho-no-mine Mountain on the coast near Miyazaki City, and the Kanmu troop tuned back near Kanmon-kaikyo Strait and headed east.

Fusosha's history textbook takes the same theory as the former government-designated textbook, but the map in Fusosha edition specifies Takachiho-no-mine Mountain on the coast near Miyazaki City, and the Kanmu troop tuned back near Kanmon-kaikyo Strait and headed east.

sen.j: また、本文では（瀬戸内海に面していない）宮崎県を出発後瀬戸内海を進むという記述になっている。
sen.e: In addition, the text describes that the troop departed from Miyazaki Prefecture (which does not face the Seto Inland Sea) and proceeded in the Seto Inland Sea.
In addition, the text describes that the troop departed from Miyazaki Prefecture (which does not face the Seto Inland Sea) and proceeded in the Seto Inland Sea.

sen.j: 北九州説
sen.e: North Kyushu theory
North Kyushu theory
North Kyushu theory

sen.j: 本来の伝承は九州北部とするもの。
sen.e: This theory argues that the tradition indicates the place of departure is in the north Kyushu.
This theory argues that the tradition indicates the place of departure is on the northern part of Kyushu region.
sen.cmt: 九州北部を修正しました。
sen.e: This theory argues that the tradition indicates the place of departure is on the northern part of Kyushu region.

sen.j: 根拠は以下の通り。
sen.e: The basis of this theory is as follows:

sen.j: 日向国ではなく日向と書かれており、日向国は景行天皇の言葉が基で命名されたとあるので、神武天皇即位以前には存在せず、日向はヒュウガではなくヒムカと読み、東向き、南向きの意か美称である。
sen.e: The text indicated Hyuga instead of Hyuga Province which was said to be named based on the word of Emperor Keiko, thus the province should not exist before the enthronement of Emperor Jinmu; the name of the place should be read Himuka instead of Hyuga, meaning it is facing the East or South, or it is an eulogistic name.

The text indicated Hyuga instead of Hyuga Province which was said to be named based on the word of Emperor Keiko, thus the province should not exist before the enthronement of Emperor Jinmu; the name of the place should be read Himuka instead of Hyuga, meaning it is facing East or South, or it is an eulogistic name.

The text indicated Hyuga instead of Hyuga Province which was said to be named based on the word of Emperor Keiko, thus the province should not exist before the enthronement of Emperor Jinmu; the name of the place should be read Himuka instead of Hyuga, meaning it is facing East or South, or it is an eulogistic name.

sen.j: 高千穂は高い山の意でその証拠に複数存在する。
sen.e: Takachiho means a high mountain, and it can be proved by the fact that there are several mountains called Takachiho.
Takachiho means a high mountain, and it can be proved by the fact that there are several mountains called Takachiho.
Takachiho means a high mountain, and it can be proved by the fact that there are several mountains called Takachiho.

sen.j: 『古事記』では天孫降臨で日向の高千穂を韓国に向かい笠沙の岬の反対側の所としている。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," Takachiho in Himuka described in tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess) is a place opposite to the cape Kasasa that faces Korea.
In "Kojiki," Takachiho in Himuka described in tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess) is a place opposite to the cape Kasasa that faces Korea.
In "Kojiki," Takachiho in Himuka described in tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess) is a place opposite to the cape Kasasa that faces Korea.

sen.j: 舟軍で出発したので現高千穂峰ではない。
sen.e: Emperor Jinmu headed for the expedition on the ship, so it can't be the present-day Takachiho-no-mine Mountain.
Emperor Jinmu headed for the expedition on the ship, so it can't be the present-day Takachiho-no-mine Mountain.
Emperor Jinmu headed for the expedition on the ship, so it can't be the present-day Takachiho-no-mine Mountain.

sen.j: 南九州を出発すると豊後海峡より流れの速い関門海峡を二度通ることになり、記述が不自然である。
sen.e: If they started from South Kyushu, they had to pass Kanmon-kaikyo Strait twice where the sea flow is fater than that in Bungo-kaikyo Strait, making the description quite odd.
If they started from Southern Kyushu, they had to pass Kanmon-kaikyo Strait twice where the sea flow is faster than that in Bungo-kaikyo Strait, making the description quite odd.
If they started from Southern Kyushu, they had to pass Kanmon-kaikyo Strait twice where the sea flow is faster than that in Bungo-kaikyo Strait, making the description quite odd.

sen.j: 寄港地の岡の水門（港）は九州北部の遠賀とされる。
sen.e: The port of call Oka no minato is considered to be Onga in the northern Kyushu.
The port of call Oka no minato is considered to be Onga in the northern Kyushu.
The port of call Oka no minato is considered to be Onga in the northern Kyushu.

sen.j: 東征して大和に到るのは北九州しか有得ない。
sen.e: North Kyushu is the only place that makes the eastern expedition arrive at Yamato.
Northern Kyushu is the only place that makes the eastern expedition arrive at Yamato.
Northern Kyushu is the only place that makes the eastern expedition arrive at Yamato.

sen.j: 南九州では四国の南に出る。
sen.e: If they headed east from South Kyushu, they would arrive in South Shikoku.
If they headed east from Southern Kyushu, they would arrive at the South side of Shikoku.
sen.cmt: South→Southern、 in South Shikoku→at the South side of Shikoku
sen.e: If they headed east from Southern Kyushu, they would arrive at the South side of Shikoku.

sen.j: 経路が瀬戸内海の北側である。
sen.e: The route passed through the north side of the Seto Island Sea.
The route passed through the north side of the Seto Island Sea.
The route passed through the north side of the Seto Island Sea.

sen.j: 南九州は熊襲の本拠地である。
sen.e: South Kyushu was the base of Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district).
Southern Kyushu was the base of Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district).
Southern Kyushu was the base of Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district).

sen.j: 神武一行は筑紫の日向を出発して、岡の水門（みなと）（福岡県）、安芸の埃の宮（えいのみや・広島県）、吉備の高島の宮（岡山県）を経て、大阪湾から奈良盆地に攻め入ろうとする。
sen.e: The Jinmu troop left Himuka in Chikushi, passed through Oka no minato (Fukuoka Prefecture), Ei no miya in Aki (Hiroshima Prefecture), and Takashima no miya in Kibi (Okayama Prefecture), and arrived at the Osaka Bay from where they attempted to penetrate into Nara Basin.

The Jinmu troop left Himuka in Chikushi, passed through Oka no minato (Fukuoka Prefecture), Ei no miya in Aki (Hiroshima Prefecture), and Takashima no miya in Kibi (Okayama Prefecture), and arrived at the Osaka Bay from where they attempted to penetrate into Nara Basin.

The Jinmu troop left Himuka in Chikushi, passed through Oka no minato (Fukuoka Prefecture), Ei no miya in Aki (Hiroshima Prefecture), and Takashima no miya in Kibi (Okayama Prefecture), and arrived at the Osaka Bay from where they attempted to penetrate into Nara Basin.

sen.j: 草香（東大阪市日下）に上陸した神武軍は最初の戦いで、応戦した長髓彦（ながすねひこ）に敗れる。
sen.e: The Jinmu Army landed on Kusaka (Higashi Osaka City) but was defeated in the first battle against the army of Nagasunehiko.
The Jinmu Army landed on Kusaka (Higashi Osaka City) was defeated in the first battle against the army of Nagasunehiko.
The Jinmu Army landed on Kusaka (Higashi Osaka City) was defeated in the first battle against the army of Nagasunehiko.

sen.j: この戦いで長兄五瀬は脛（すね）に矢傷を負う。
sen.e: In this battle, the eldest brother Itsuse injured his shin by an arrow.
In this battle, the eldest brother Itsuse injured his shin by an arrow.
In this battle, the eldest brother Itsuse injured his shin by an arrow.

sen.j: 西からの侵攻をあきらめ、東から攻めるべく紀伊半島を迂回する。
sen.e: They gave up invading from the west and made a detour around the Kii Peninsula to penetrate from the east.
They gave up invading from the west and made a detour around the Kii Peninsula to penetrate from the east.
They gave up invading from the west and made a detour around the Kii Peninsula to penetrate from the east.

sen.j: 途中五瀬は傷がもとで「雄の港」で没し竈山（和歌山市和田竈山神社）に葬られたとする。
sen.e: During the detour, Itsuse died of the wound at O no minato and buried in Kamayama (Kamayama jinja Shrine in Wada, Wakayama City).
During the detour, Itsuse died of the wound at O no minato and was buried in Kamayama (Kamayama jinja Shrine in Wada, Wakayama City).
During the detour, Itsuse died of the wound at O no minato and was buried in Kamayama (Kamayama jinja Shrine in Wada, Wakayama City).

sen.j: 名草戸畔を倒しさらに東に進むが、熊野（和歌山県）と伊勢の境、荒坂の津（三重県熊野市）で暴風に会い難破する。
sen.e: The army defeated Nagusatobe headed further east, but their ships were wrecked by the storm in Arasaka-no-tsu (Kumano City, Mie Prefecture) on the border between Kumano (Wakayama Prefecture) and Ise.
The army defeated Nagusatobe headed further east, but their ships were wrecked by the storm in Arasaka-no-tsu (Kumano City, Mie Prefecture) on the border between Kumano (Wakayama Prefecture) and Ise.
The army defeated Nagusatobe headed further east, but their ships were wrecked by the storm in Arasaka-no-tsu (Kumano City, Mie Prefecture) on the border between Kumano (Wakayama Prefecture) and Ise.

sen.j: やむなく八咫烏（やたのからす）の案内で、熊野山中を突破し、菟田（うだ）の穿邑（うがちむら）（奈良県宇陀郡菟田野町）に至る。
sen.e: Following the yatakarasu's guide, the army went through the Kumano mountain and arrived at Ugachi mura in Uda (Utano-cho, Uda district, Nara Prefecture).
Following the yatakarasu's guide, the army went through the Kumano mountain and arrived at Ugachi mura in Uda (Utano-cho, Uda County, Nara Prefecture).
Following the yatakarasu's guide, the army went through the Kumano mountain and arrived at Ugachi mura in Uda (Utano-cho, Uda County, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: ここで兄猾（えうかし）を破り、奈良盆地への侵攻を図る。
sen.e: There they defeated Eukashi and attempted to invade into Nara Basin.
There they defeated Eukashi and attempted to invade into Nara Basin.
There they defeated Eukashi and attempted to invade into Nara Basin.

sen.j: その後も磯城津彦などとの激しい戦いを繰り広げ、椎根津彦の作戦で青垣山の防衛線を突破して奈等盆地内に侵入する。
sen.e: They fought some more severe fights against Shikitsuhiko and other enemies before they broke through the defense line in Mt. Aokaki thanks to the Shiinetsuhiko's strategy, and they succeeded in penetrating into Nara Basin.
They fought some more severe fights against Shikitsuhiko and other enemies and they broke through the defense line in Mt. Aokaki by the Shiinetsuhiko's operation to invade Nara Basin.
sen.cmt: 後半部分をいくつか修正しました。
sen.e: They fought some more severe fights against Shikitsuhiko and other enemies and they broke through the defense line in Mt. Aokaki by the Shiinetsuhiko's operation to invade Nara Basin.

sen.j: さらに盆地内で長髓彦（ながすねひこ）との戦いは続くが、ニギハヤヒの子、ウマシマデが叔父の長髓彦を斬って、神武に帰順する。
sen.e: In the Basin, they further fought against Nagasunehiko, but Umashimade, a son of Nigihayahi, slew his uncle Nagasunehiko and submitted to Jinmu.
In the Basin, they further fought against Nagasunehiko, but Umashimade, a son of Nigihayahi, slew his uncle Nagasunehiko and submitted to Jinmu.
In the Basin, they further fought against Nagasunehiko, but Umashimade, a son of Nigihayahi, slew his uncle Nagasunehiko and submitted to Jinmu.

sen.j: その後も抵抗する者たちを制圧し、奈良盆地内の平定は終わる。
sen.e: The Jinmu army continued to suppress the resistance and concluded to pacify Nara Basin.
The Jinmu army continued to suppress the resistance and concluded to pacify Nara Basin.
The Jinmu army continued to suppress the resistance and concluded to pacify Nara Basin.
